notesStmt.note: Title from caption title and opening lines of text.
Dated at end: Giuen at our lapace of Westminster, the nineteenth day of Nouember, in the third yeere of our reigne of Great Britaine, France and Ireland.
Arms 9; Steele notation: se- committed 2) or escape.
Authorizing sheriffs to pursue rebels across county borders -- STC.
Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ‚ùß By the King.
div.p: WHereas the cu≈øtody and ≈øafe keeping of our ≈øeuerall Counties and Shires of our Realme of England, are by our ancient Commonlawes committed to ≈øeuerall Shiriffes, being ancient Con≈øeruators of the Peace, and Mini≈øters of Iu≈øtice within the ≈øame, who by force of their Offices may a≈ø≈øemble, and take the power and ≈øtrength of our ≈øayd Counties and Shires committed to their charge, not onely for the due execution of Iu≈øtice, but al≈øo for the pre≈øeruation of our Peace, and the ≈øpeedy and timely di≈ø≈øolution and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of all In≈øurrections, Rebellions, outragious Riots, Routes, and other exorbitant and vnlawfull a≈ø≈øemblies, to the end that ≈øuch dangerous attempts might bee ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in their beginnings, and our louing Subiects liue and exerci≈øe their ≈øeueral vocations in al peace and plentie; The good effect of the execution of which Lawes hath well appeared, in that the mo≈øt dete≈øtable and diabolicall Rebellion of Percy and his Complices in our Counties of Warwicke, Worce≈øter, and Stafford, (that had bene ≈øo ≈øecretly contriued, and ≈øo long in hatching) was by the peaceable Mini≈øters of our Lawes, and by due execution of their Offices, without any extraordinary power or forces, mo≈øt loyally, re≈øolutely, and ≈øpeedily ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed: And whereas ≈øome que≈øtion or ≈øcruple hath bene (as wee are enformed) mooued among≈øt ≈øome of the vulgar, Whether any of our Sheriffes may, with the Power of their ≈øeuerall Counties or Shires, in pur≈øuit of Rebels and Traitours, follow them into any other County, Albeit by the Lawes of this Realme, Sheriffes, as it falleth out in dayly experience, in priuate ca≈øes betweene party and party (matters of no ≈øuch eminent and publike danger and con≈øequence as this is) iu≈øtly and lawfully doe the like, whereof Wee pre≈øume few or none can be ignorant: Yet Wee meaning to giue ≈øati≈øfaction to all, doe hereby publi≈øh and declare, That ≈øuch pur≈øuit of Rebels and Traitors into other Counties, is not onely in ≈øuch ca≈øes lawfull and iu≈øtifiable, But, that if any of our Subiects being thereunto required by any of our Sheriffes, ≈øhall not follow and a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in ≈øuch pur≈øuit, that they are to bee ≈øeuerely and ≈øharpely puni≈øhed for their high contempt and offence in that behalfe.

But if in ≈øuch pur≈øuite the Sheriffe of the ≈øame Countie or Shire (whereunto ≈øuch Rebels or Traytors ≈øhal flye or e≈øcape) ≈øhall al≈øo come with the power of his Countie before ≈øuch Rebels or Traytors bee apprehended or ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, Then the Sheriffe ≈øo pur≈øuing from any
other Countie or Shire ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt and ioyne with the Sheriffe in his proper Countie or Shire, for the apprehen≈øion or ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of ≈øuch Rebels and Traitors. And it ≈øuch Rebels or Traytors ≈øhall flie or e≈øcape into any hou≈øe or other place of ≈øtrength and defence, and ≈øhall not yeeld them≈øelues being thereunto required by the Sheriffe or any of his companie that ≈øo ≈øhall pur≈øue them, but ob≈øtinately and wilfully make re≈øi≈øtance, That then it ≈øhall be lawfull for euery ≈øuch Sheriffe ≈øo pur≈øuing with ≈øuch power and ≈øtrength, as he ≈øhall collect, or ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, to beate downe, burne, or otherwi≈øe wa≈øt any ≈øuch hou≈øe or place of defence for the better apprehen≈øion or ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of ≈øuch Rebels and Traytors. And albeit we de≈øire that ≈øuch indu≈øtrie and care may be taken, as that ≈øuch offendors may be apprehended aliue, Yet wee let it be knowen, that if otherwi≈øe through their rebellious ob≈øtinacy and re≈øi≈øtance, ≈øuch Rebellion cannot be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed; That it ≈øhall be lawfull and iu≈øtifiable in tho≈øe ca≈øes of nece≈ø≈øitie, for the Sheriffe and his Company a≈ø≈øi≈øting him, to kill and de≈øtroy ≈øuch Traytors and Rebels. And as the faithfull endeuours of our louing Subiects with ≈øuch alacrity as they haue ≈øhewed in this late Rebellion, is very acceptable vnto vs; So if in any ≈øuch ca≈øe any per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhall vnder pretence of our publique ≈øeruice, maliciou≈øly and vniu≈øtly ≈øeeke to reuenge any priuate quarrell, We let them know that they ≈øhall not e≈øcape without ≈øeuere and condigne puni≈øhments according to their demerits in that behalfe.
div.closer:
Giuen at our Palace of We≈øtmin≈øter, the nineteenth day of Nouember, in the third yeereof our Reigne of Great Britaine, France and Ireland.
God ≈øaue the King.

div.p: ‚ùß Imprinted at London by Robert Barker, Printer to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maie≈øtie.
